desc: MEN1 encodes a transcriptional repressor that regulates cell proliferation. Germline missense and truncating mutations of MEN1 are found in the dominantly inherited Multiple Endocrine Neoplasia syndrome, and somatic inactivating mutations are found in endocrine tumors such as pancreatic neuroendocrine tumors.

Multiple endocrine neoplasia type 1 (MEN1) is a dominantly inherited tumor syndrome that results from the mutation of the tumor suppressor gene Men1, which encodes menin. Menin interacts with multiple proteins that play critical roles in the regulation of cell proliferation, including JunD, Smad, and activator of S-phase kinase (PMID:16740708, 9103196, 9215690). Mutations of the MEN1 gene cause tumors in pituitary, parathyroid, lung, and enteropancreatic endocrine tissues (PMID: 14992727). Patients with MEN 1 are found to have either mis-sense or truncation mutations within the MEN1 open reading frame, while the second allele is subject to loss of heterozygosity in tumors from these patients (PMID: 9103196). Both MEN1 alleles are inactivated somatically in a variety of sporadic endocrine tumors (PMID: 9361035, 9241276, 9766672). MEN1 was found in a screen for transcriptional repressors of the human telomerase catalytic subunit gene, hTERT (PMID: 12837246). The AP-1 transcription factor JunD and the putative transcription factor Pem, Nf-ÎºB , Smad-3 , replication protein A, nm23, and FANCD2 have been reported to interact with menin (PMID: 9989505, 10500243, 11500056, 11526476, 11274402, 12509449, 11302744, 12874027, 14992727). 44% of Pancreatic neuroendocrine tumors (PanNETs) had somatic inactivating mutations in MEN1(PMID: 21252315).
